STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 2, 2024
Jennifer Savage
BENZIE/MANISTEE DHHS
1672 US-31 SOUTH S,
MANISTEE, MI, 49660-8942
Re: License #: CP510201273
Dear Ms. Savage:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
06/07/24. Due to the violation of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Samantha Way, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line
supervisor, when siblings in care are placed apart. •
Parents who are a member of a participating
household. • Youth ages 14 and older. • Foster
parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers
One of three files reviewed contained two treatment plans that were signed more
than thirty days from the date of the service plan. Therefore, the signature page
was not uploaded into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report
date.
2

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that
incidents reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those
incidents named under the rule are to be submitted.
• DCWL review of Corrective Action Plans (CAP). The agency was
informed that starting January 1, 2024, interim and renewal audit CAP's
will be reviewed with the agency at three months and six months. The
assigned Consultant for the agency will work with the agency in
conducting CAP reviews. This process for special investigation CAP
reviews was implemented previously.
• Rule 400.12209 (2) (a) Orientation and Training. The agency was
informed that all the training requirements listed under (2) (a) are required
yearly for foster care workers carrying a caseload as well as for
supervisors who may be carrying a caseload.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was not requested or required at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows: The agency
submitted an approved corrective action plan on 08/16/23 in response to two
violations established during the renewal inspection completed on 07/18/23. The
current interim inspection did not establish any repeat violations indicating the
agency CAP was successful in preventing violations of the policy.
3

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators Assessment was reviewed. The assessment was
thorough in detailing the agency's internal quality assurance process and review.
Barriers noted were the loss of a foster care allocation and staff having to absorb
additional responsibilities. Another barrier was maintaining compliance with cases
with multiple large sibling groups. The assessment also addressed the agency's
efforts in addressing the 2023 CAP which was successful in preventing repeat
violations.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
Staff interviewed reported feeling very supported by their supervisor and the
agency administration. Staff reported the agency is small which has helped in
creating a well functioning and supportive team. Each staff reported they like
working for the agency for the reasons mentioned above.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a local DHHS office in Benzie County. The office is well equipped
and maintained. CHRI documents were secured and a cross shredder is available.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
June 27, 2024
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 2, 2024
________________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
